results.title: What Did Stephen Sondheim Really Think of ‘Rent’?
results.abstract: The composer served as something of a mentor to Jonathan Larson and spoke frankly about the show after the younger man’s death.

multimedia.caption: Jonathan Larson, left, sometimes turned to Stephen Sondheim for advice.
multimedia.copyright: From left: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times; Oliver Morris/Getty Images

results.title: After 15 Years of Infighting, James Brown’s Estate Is Sold
results.abstract: The sale to Primary Wave Music, for an estimated $90 million, provides resources to ultimately realize the musician’s wish to fund scholarships for needy children.
results.byline: By Ben Sisario and Steve Knopper

multimedia.caption: The Primary Wave deal is being described as a major step toward underwriting scholarships for children that Brown had outlined in his will.

results.title: Golden Globes Nominations 2022: The Complete List
results.abstract: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association announced a list that showed some improvement on its goal of diversifying the awards. But questions still hover over the ceremony.

multimedia.caption: Nominated for Globes were the “King Richard” performers Aunjanue Ellis, left, and Will Smith (with Mikayla Bartholomew, second from left, Saniyya Sidney, Demi Singleton and Danielle Lawson).
multimedia.copyright: Warner Brothers Pictures, via Associated Press

results.title: Vicente Fernández, the King of Machos and Heartbreak
results.abstract: The singer’s brand of machismo may have frayed, but for many, he was the ideal of what it means to be hard-working, hard-loving Mexican man.

multimedia.caption: The singer Vicente Fernández, who was the king of ranchera music, performed at the Latin Grammy Awards in 2019. He died on Sunday at 81.

results.title: ‘Succession’ Season Finale Recap: Do Not Pass Go
results.abstract: The final episode of Season 3 brought new alliances, new betrayals and new reminders that when Logan doesn’t like how the game is going, he just changes the rules.

multimedia.caption: A deal with the devil: Matthew Macfadyen in the season finale of “Succession.”

results.title: Heirs Sue to Claim Mondrian Painting in Philadelphia Museum of Art
results.abstract: The lawsuit argues that Piet Mondrian, the artist, never lost title to the painting, which was looted by the Nazis and has been in the museum since 1943.

multimedia.caption: “Composition with Blue (Schilderij No. 1: Lozenge with 2 Lines and Blue)," 1926, by Piet Mondrian

results.title: Review: In Time for the Holidays, Radiant Praetorius Carols
results.abstract: Tenet Vocal Artists marked the 450th anniversary of the German Baroque composer Michael Praetorius’s birth, and the 400th of his death.

multimedia.caption: Tenet Vocal Artists performing works by the composer Michael Praetorius on Saturday at St. Paul’s Lutheran Church in Manhattan.

results.title: Review: ‘Density’ Keeps Expanding the Flute’s Universe
results.abstract: Now in its eighth year, Claire Chase’s multidecade project to create a modern repertory for her instrument shows no signs of slowing.

multimedia.caption: Claire Chase playing Wang Lu’s “Aftertouch,” one of three premieres in the eighth installment of “Density 2036,” at the Kitchen.

results.title: ‘Insecure’ Recap, Season 5, Episode 8: Fears and Desires
results.abstract: This week, Issa is thriving personally and professionally, but a series of dreams (or nightmares) inject uncertainty into her situation.

multimedia.caption: Issa Rae in “Insecure.”

results.title: Vicente Fernández, el rey de los machos y el desamor
results.abstract: Puede que el machismo encarnado por sus canciones se haya desgastado, pero su música seguirá siendo parte de las fibras sonoras de lo latinoamericano y lo latino en Estados Unidos.

multimedia.caption: The singer Vicente Fernández, who was the king of ranchera music, performed at the Latin Grammy Awards in 2019. He died on Sunday at 81.

results.title: Nai-Ni Chen, Whose Dances Merged East and West, Dies at 62
results.abstract: Ms. Chen, who founded the Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company in 1988, died while swimming in Hawaii, where she was vacationing.

multimedia.caption: Nai-Ni Chen performing in “Passage to the Silk River” at New York City Center’s Fall for Dance Festival in 2005. “I like to integrate both aesthetics, Eastern and Western,” Ms. Chen, who founded the company named for her, once said.
multimedia.copyright: Stephanie Berger for The New York Times

results.title: Humphrey Davies, Noted Translator of Arabic Literature, Dies at 74
results.abstract: He introduced numerous novels, including works by the Nobel laureate Naguib Mahfouz, to English language readers.

multimedia.caption: Humphrey Davies in 2009. He was one of the premier translators of Arabic fiction and non-fiction, rendering novels into English of major Arab writers, including the Nobel Prize-winning Naguib Mahfouz.

results.title: Suzette Winter, Who Documented Hollywood’s Golden Age, Dies at 90
results.abstract: She and her husband produced more than 30 rosy biographical films for television about the era’s biggest stars.

multimedia.caption: Suzette Winter Feldman and her husband, Gene, right, posed with the actor Gregory Peck in an undated photo. The couple produced more than two dozen film biographies of Hollywood figures.

results.title: An Encyclopedic New Guide to Cocktails Stirred, Shaken, Rolled, Tossed, Swizzled, Muddled...
results.abstract: “The Oxford Companion to Spirits and Cocktails,” edited by David Wondrich with Noah Rothbaum, is an authoritative work, nearly a decade in the making.
des_facet: The Oxford Companion to Spirits and Cocktails (Book)

results.title: Penguin Random House Defends Effort to Buy Simon & Schuster
results.abstract: The Biden administration has challenged the deal over concerns it would harm authors, but the publisher said that argument is a misunderstanding of how the book industry works.
results.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter

multimedia.caption: Penguin Random House has offered $2.18 billion for Simon & Schuster, a deal that would further consolidate the publishing industry.
multimedia.copyright: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times

results.title: When Did Every Celebrity Become a Creative Director?
results.abstract: Famous brand ambassadors have fancy new titles now.

multimedia.caption: Cardi B at the release party for Whipshots, a vodka-infused whipped cream. She is a partner at the company.

results.title: Review: In ‘Best of Enemies,’ a TV Duel Becomes a Theater Gem
results.abstract: James Graham’s new play draws parallels between the bad-tempered 1968 debates between William F. Buckley and Gore Vidal and the rancorous public arena of today.

multimedia.caption: David Harewood, left, as William F. Buckley and Charles Edwards as Gore Vidal in “Best of Enemies” at the Young Vic theater in London.

results.title: Adele’s ‘30’ Crosses a Million Sales and Holds at No. 1
results.abstract: The singer’s first album in six years became the first release to reach that milestone since Taylor Swift’s “Evermore” a year ago. But in 2015, Adele’s “25” sold 3.4 million its first week.

multimedia.caption: Adele held the No. 1 spot on the Billboard album chart for a third week with “30.”

results.title: ‘The Rise and Fall of LuLaRoe’ Review: Success? That’s a Stretch.
results.abstract: This formulaic documentary focuses on the individuals swindled by the multilevel marketing company known for leggings, LuLaRoe.
des_facet: The Rise and Fall of LuLaRoe (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Sharon Tucker, a former LuLaRoe retailer, and her son Elijah, a former LuLaRoe employee, look at unsold leggings in “The Rise and Fall of LuLaRoe.”

results.title: In Nadifa Mohamed’s Latest, a Man Hangs for a Murder He Didn’t Commit
results.abstract: A Booker Prize finalist, “The Fortune Men” fictionalizes the story of the Somali seaman who became the last man to be hanged by the state in Cardiff, Wales, in 1952.

multimedia.caption: The Somali-British writer Nadifa Mohamed returns to a real-life case to explore the centuries-long legacies of the British Empire, of the nation’s anti-Black violence and the institution of prison in the West.

results.title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘American Auto’ and ‘MTV Unplugged’
results.abstract: NBC debuts a sitcom about bumbling auto executives. And Tony Bennett sings with Lady Gaga on “MTV Unplugged.”
des_facet: The Nutcracker and The Mouse King (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: Michael Benjamin Washington, left, and Humphrey Ker in “American Auto.”

results.title: Vicente Fernández, ‘El Rey’ of Mexican Ranchera Music, Is Dead at 81
results.abstract: A beloved Mexican singer, Mr. Fernández was known for his powerful operatic range and marathon performances, delivered in a signature charro outfit and intricately embroidered sombrero.

multimedia.caption: Vicente Fernández at Madison Square Garden in 2008. He was known for giving epic performances in which he relished the give-and-take with his fans.
multimedia.copyright: Michael Nagle for The New York Times

results.title: Spielberg’s ‘West Side Story’ Opens to Tepid Box Office Receipts
results.abstract: Musicals often take time to build an audience, but can this remake, with little star power, compete with franchises and spectacles?

multimedia.caption: Ariana DeBose, center, as Anita in “West Side Story,” which opened in theaters this weekend.

results.title: Marjorie Tallchief, Acclaimed Ballerina, Is Dead at 95
results.abstract: A versatile artist who performed with the Paris Opera Ballet, she was the younger sister of the famed dancer Maria Tallchief.

multimedia.caption: Marjorie Tallchief in 1966. One critic described her as “a brilliant, dynamic dancer with a svelte and flexible body,” adding, “Through her quasi-acrobatic virtuosity, she embodies the perfect dancer for our time.”

results.title: Robert Farris Thompson, ‘Guerrilla Scholar’ of African Art, Dies at 88
results.abstract: He revolutionized the study of the cultures of Africa and the Americas by combining art history with anthropology, sociology and ethnomusicology.
des_facet: Flash of the Spirit: African and Afro-American Art and Philosophy (Book)

multimedia.caption: The art historian Robert Farris Thompson in an undated photo. He spoke and wrote of African civilizations as infinitely varied ethical, philosophical and aesthetic systems.

results.title: Review: ‘Magic Flute’ Welcomes Children Back to the Met
results.abstract: A winning cast opened the company’s holiday season with a trimmed, English-language version of Mozart’s classic.

multimedia.caption: Tamino (the tenor Matthew Polenzani) and a trio of dancing bears in “The Magic Flute” at the Metropolitan Opera.

results.title: ‘Sesame Street’ Was Always Political
results.abstract: The beloved children’s show has been a recurrent culture-war target, but a documentary on HBO shows how social purpose was built into it.
des_facet: Street Gang: How We Got to Sesame Street (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Jim Henson with Big Bird, as seen in “Street Gang: How We Got Sesame Street.” The HBO documentary uses file footage and new interviews to detail the early years of the influential show.

results.title: Anne Rice, Who Spun Gothic Tales of Vampires, Dies at 80
results.abstract: She wrote more than 30 novels, including the best seller “Interview With the Vampire,” which became a hit movie starring Tom Cruise and Brad Pitt.

multimedia.caption: Anne Rice in 2016 in New York. “What matters to me is that people know that my books are serious and that they are meant to make a difference and that they are meant to be literature,” she once said.
multimedia.copyright: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times

results.title: An East Side Sondheim Story
results.abstract: After a car crash, a New York legend offers his help, from this week's Metropolitan Diary.

results.title: Kate McKinnon Returns to ‘S.N.L.’ as Dr. Anthony Fauci
results.abstract: McKinnon wasted no time playing numerous roles in a “Saturday Night Live” episode in which Billie Eilish was both host and musical guest.

multimedia.caption: Kate McKinnon played Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, among others, on “Saturday Night Live” this week.

results.title: The Big Question: Could Peloton Sue Over Its ‘And Just Like That’ Appearance?
results.abstract: A Peloton stationary bike played a pivotal role on the new HBO Max “Sex and the City” revival, whose premiere preceded a drop in the company’s stock price on Friday.

multimedia.caption: Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker) and Mr. Big (Chris Noth) in the premiere of “And Just Like That.”

results.title: Silent Films Offer Rare Glimpses of Life in 1920s Ireland
results.abstract: Shot by an American ornithologist in the early years of Irish independence, the footage turned up in the archives of the Chicago Academy of Sciences and is being restored.

multimedia.caption: Boys with a horse, probably in rural County Kerry. Manus McManus, the film collections and acquisitions manager for the Irish Film Institute, hopes Irish viewers will recognize some of the people in the film.

results.title: ‘La verdad de una sociedad sale de forma natural’: Óscar Murillo, el artista que apuesta por la colaboración
results.abstract: El pintor, criado en Londres, considera una “infiltración” el hecho de que sus lienzos con conciencia de clase acaben en las paredes de los coleccionistas.

multimedia.caption: El artista Óscar Murillo en su estudio de Londres, adonde se trasladó siendo un niño de 11 años desde un pueblo industrial de Colombia.
multimedia.copyright: Andrew Testa para The New York Times

results.title: ‘Diana, the Musical’ to End Broadway Run on Dec. 19
results.abstract: The royal musical had a bumpy road to Broadway, from a delay caused by the pandemic to a filmed version of the show on Netflix that was widely panned.

multimedia.caption: Jeanna de Waal as Diana and Roe Hartrampf as Prince Charles in “Diana, the Musical.”
